sen.j: あんパン（餡パン）は、菓子パンの一種で、中に餡が入っていることを特徴とする。
sen.e: Anpan (a round soft bread including azuki bean paste in its center) is a kind of a sweet bun including 'an' (sweet bean paste).
sen.cmt: 餡→an、冠詞のanと区別するため 'an'としました
sen.e: Anpan (a round soft bread with azuki bean paste in the center) is a kind of a sweet bun with 'an' (sweet bean paste).
Anpan (a round soft bread with azuki bean paste in the center) is a kind of a sweet bun with 'an' (sweet bean paste).

sen.j: 明治時代に日本人の口に合うように発明された日本独自のパンで、つぶあん、こしあん、まれに白あんやうぐいすあんのものがある。
sen.e: Anpan was a bun unique to Japan, invented to meet the tastes of Japanese during the Meiji period with such variations of bean pastes as tsubuan (sweet bean paste containing pieces of azuki beans skin), koshian (smooth bean paste), and rarely, shiroan (white bean paste) and uguisuan (uguisu-greenbean paste).

Anpan is type of bun unique to Japan, invented to meet the tastes of Japanese during the Meiji Period with such variations of bean pastes as tsubuan (sweet bean paste containing pieces of azuki bean skin), koshian (smooth bean paste), and in rare cases, shiroan (white bean paste) and uguisuan (uguisu-greenbean paste).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Anpan is type of bun unique to Japan, invented to meet the tastes of Japanese during the Meiji Period with such variations of bean pastes as tsubuan (sweet bean paste containing pieces of azuki bean skin), koshian (smooth bean paste), and in rare cases, shiroan (white bean paste) and uguisuan (uguisu-greenbean paste).

sen.j: 外国から輸入した文化を日本向けに改良した物の例として挙げられる事がしばしばある。
sen.e: It is often cited as a concrete sample that a variety of foreign cultures introduced to Japan were tailored to meet the need of Japanese.
It is often cited as a concrete sample that a variety of things from foreign cultures introduced to Japan are tailored to meet the needs of Japanese.
sen.cmt: added "of things"; were > are; need > needs
sen.e: It is often cited as a concrete sample that a variety of things from foreign cultures introduced to Japan are tailored to meet the needs of Japanese.

sen.j: 最も典型的な形状は、平たく、円盤のようなもの。
sen.e: The most typical shape of anpan is rounded flat like an disc.
The most typical shape of anpan is round and flat like a disc.
The most typical shape of anpan is round and flat like a disc.

sen.j: また、芋あんぱん、クリあんぱんなどの豆以外の餡を使ったものや、桜餡や鶯餡を使った季節ものもある。
sen.e: It also contains sweet pastes made of ingredients except for beans such as imo anpan (sweet potato paste bun), kuri anpan (chestnut paste bun), or made of seasonal ingredients used sakura-an (cherry blossom flavored bean paste) and uguisu-an (uguisu-green bean paste).

It also contains sweet pastes made of ingredients other than beans such as those used in imo anpan (sweet potato paste bun) and kuri anpan (chestnut paste bun), or made from seasonal ingredients using sakura-an (cherry blossom flavored bean paste) and uguisu-an (uguisu-green bean paste).

It also contains sweet pastes made of ingredients other than beans such as those used in imo anpan (sweet potato paste bun) and kuri anpan (chestnut paste bun), or made from seasonal ingredients using sakura-an (cherry blossom flavored bean paste) and uguisu-an (uguisu-green bean paste).

sen.j: なお、あんパンの上に振りかけてある粒状のものはゴマと誤解されがちだが、実際はケシの実（ポピーの種）である（芽が出ないように炒ってある）。
sen.e: Incidentally, grains sprinkled on an anpan is likely to misunderstand as sesame seeds; in fact, they are poppy seeds (they are lightly roasted to stop sprout growing).
The grain that is sprinkled on anpan is often mistaken as sesame seeds, when in fact they are poppy seeds (they are lightly roasted to keep them from sprouting).
The grain that is sprinkled on anpan is often mistaken as sesame seeds, when in fact they are poppy seeds (they are lightly roasted to keep them from sprouting).

sen.j: 揚げパンなどにも、アンパンがあり、トーストに餡を挟んだ揚げパンなどもある。
sen.e: Agepan (deep fried bread) includes anpan, or sometimes, deep fried two slices of toasted bread containing 'an' placed between them.
Agepan (deep fried bread) contains anpan, and sometimes 'an" is placed between two deep fried slices of toasted bread.
Agepan (deep fried bread) contains anpan, and sometimes 'an" is placed between two slices of toasted bread and deep fried.
sen.cmt: 揚げたパンに餡をはさむのではなく、あんをはさんで揚げてあると考えられるので、語順を変えました。

sen.j: 木村屋（現・木村屋總本店）創業者であり茨城県出身の元士族・木村安兵衛とその次男の木村英三郎が考案し、1874年に銀座の店で売り出したところ好評を博したとされる。
sen.e: Originated by Yasubei KIMURA, who was a founder of Kimuraya (now, Kimuraya-sohonten (Japan's first bakery)) and former samurai from Ibaragi Prefecture, and his second son, Eizaburo KIMURA, anpan went on the market at their bakery in Ginza in 1874, and then was being well received.

Anpan was originally created by Yasubei KIMURA, the founder of Kimuraya (known today as Kimuraya-sohonten (Japan's first bakery) and a former samurai from Ibaragi Prefecture, and with his second son named Eizaburo KIMURA, they put anpan on the market at their bakery in Ginza in 1874 where it was well received.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Anpan was originally created by Yasubei KIMURA, the founder of Kimuraya (known today as Kimuraya-sohonten (Japan's first bakery) and a former samurai from Ibaragi Prefecture, and with his second son named Eizaburo KIMURA, they put anpan on the market at their bakery in Ginza in 1874 where it was well received.

sen.j: 翌年、山岡鉄舟を通して明治天皇にも献上された。
sen.e: The next year, it was presented to Meiji Emperor through Tesshu YAMAOKA.
It was presented to the Meiji Emperor the next year through Tesshu YAMAOKA.
It was presented to the Meiji Emperor the next year through Tesshu YAMAOKA.

sen.j: これが新聞や口伝で広まり、あんパンと共に木村屋の全国的な知名度も上がった。
sen.e: This news was spread through newspapers and word of mouth; as a result, the brand names of both Kimuraya bakery and its anpan were highly recognized all over the country.
This news was spread through newspapers and word of mouth, resulting in the brand names of both Kimuraya bakery and its anpan being highly recognized all over the country.
This news was spread through newspapers and word of mouth, resulting in the brand names of both Kimuraya bakery and its anpan being highly recognized all over the country.

sen.j: なお、4月4日に明治天皇に献上されたであったことから4月4日はあんぱんの日とされている。
sen.e: The presentation of anpan to Meiji Emperor on April 4 led to settle that day as Anpan no hi (Anpan Day).
The presentation of anpan to the Meiji Emperor was on April 4th, which led to the day being called Anpan no hi (Anpan day).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: The presentation of anpan to the Meiji Emperor was on April 4th, which led to the day being called Anpan no hi (Anpan day).

sen.j: 元祖木村屋のあんパンは、パン酵母（ホップを用いたもの）の代わりに、饅頭と同様に日本酒酵母を含む酒種（酒母、麹に酵母を繁殖させたもの）を使い、中心の窪みにサクラの塩漬けを入れており、パンでありながらも和菓子の部類に入れても良いようなものである。
sen.e: The original anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was made by using sakadane (shubo (yeast mash) cultured in the mixture of koji (rice malt) and yeast) including sake yeast for making manju (confection made by wrapping a core of sweetened red bean paste in a skin of wheat-flour dough and steaming), and putting a salt-picked cherry blossom on the small dent in the center of an anpan, so that anpan has two characters; a kind of bread and a kind of Japanese sweet.
sen.cmt: あんパンと饅頭の違いがわかるように、饅頭→confection made by wrapping a core of sweetened red bean paste in a skin of wheat-flour dough and steamingと訳出しました
sen.e: The original anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was made by using sakadane (shubo [yeast mash] cultured in a mixture of koji [rice malt] and yeast), including sake yeast for making manju (a confection made by wrapping a core of sweetened red bean paste in a skin of wheat-flour dough and steaming it), and putting a salt-picked cherry blossom on the small dent in the center of the anpan so it would have two characters: a kind of bread and a kind of Japanese sweet.
sen.cmt: changed double parenthesis to []; changed semi-colon to a colon; fixed grammar
sen.e: The original anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was made by using sakadane (shubo [yeast mash] cultured in a mixture of koji [rice malt] and yeast), including sake yeast for making manju (a confection made by wrapping a core of sweetened red bean paste in a skin of wheat-flour dough and steaming it), and putting a salt-pickled cherry blossom on the small dent in the center of the anpan so it would have two characters: a kind of bread and a kind of Japanese sweet.

sen.j: 北海道札幌市豊平区月寒では、明治時代後期に、木村屋のアンパンの話を元に月寒あんぱんを作り出したが、製法や実物などの情報がなかったため、パンと言うよりも月餅に近いサイズと食感を持ったものとなった。
sen.e: Based on the success story of the Kimuraya's anpan, Tsukisamu anpan was produced in Tsukisamu, Toyohira Ward, Sapporo City Hokkaido during the late Meiji period; however, the luck of the information about the recipe and the real anpan itself resulted in producing one with the size and texture of geppei (a Chinese baked cake containing red bean paste, nuts, dried fruits, and so on, and wrapped with white flour dough) rather than anpan

Due to the success story of Kimuraya's anpan, Tsukisamu anpan began being produced in Tsukisamu, Toyohira Ward, Sapporo City Hokkaido during the late Meiji Period; however, since there was no information on the recipe of the real anpan, it ended up being produced with the size and texture of geppei (a Chinese baked cake containing ingredients like red bean paste, nuts, and dried fruits and then wrapped with white flour dough) rather than the original anpan.
sen.cmt: Based on > Due to; added period; added "original" before "anpan"; fixed grammar
sen.e: Due to the success story of Kimuraya's anpan, Tsukisamu anpan began being produced in Tsukisamu, Toyohira Ward, Sapporo City, Hokkaido during the late Meiji Period; however, since there was no information on the recipe of the real anpan, it ended up being produced with the size and texture of geppei (a Chinese baked cake containing ingredients like red bean paste, nuts, and dried fruits and then wrapped with white flour dough) rather than the original anpan.

sen.j: 当時の陸軍連隊の兵士にとって、重労働の後のエネルギー源としてもてはやされ、それによって出来た道路に「アンパン道路」と名付けるほどだった。
sen.e: The Tsukisamu anpan became so popular for soldiers of the Army regiment at that time as their energy source after hard work that the road constructed by them was named 'Anpan Road' after the anpan they ate.
Tsukisamu anpan became so popular with the soldiers of the army at the time, becoming their energy source after hard work, that the road they constructed was named 'Anpan Road.'
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Tsukisamu anpan became so popular with the soldiers of the army at the time, becoming their energy source after hard work, that the road they constructed was named 'Anpan Road.'

sen.j: 現在では、月寒にある「ほんま」にて販売されている。
sen.e: Now, it is sold at HONMA., Ltd in Tsukisamu.
It is now sold at HONMA., Ltd in Tsukisamu.
sen.cmt: Now, it is > It is now
sen.e: It is now sold at HONMA., Ltd in Tsukisamu.

sen.j: 青森県北津軽郡板柳町には、川口あんぱんと呼ばれる小麦粉を原料としたカステラ風の生地で白餡を包んだ饅頭状の和菓子が存在する。
sen.e: Kawaguchi anpan has existed in Itayanagi-machi, Kitatsugaru-gun, Aomori Prefecture, which is a manju-like Japanese sweet wrapping shiroan with castella-like sponge cake made of wheat flour.
Kawaguchi anpan from Itayanagi-machi, Kitatsugaru-gun, Aomori Prefecture is a manju-like Japanese sweet wrapping of shiroan with castella-like sponge cake made from wheat flour.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally and smoothly
sen.e: Kawaguchi anpan from Itayanagi-machi, Kitatsugaru-gun, Aomori Prefecture is a manju-like Japanese sweet wrapping of shiroan with castella-like sponge cake made from wheat flour.

sen.j: これは明治初期に考案されたといわれるが、月寒あんぱん同様、名称以外に詳細な情報が存在しなかったため、既存の製菓技術を用いてオーブンで仕上げた焼き菓子になったと見られる。
sen.e: Originated early in the Meiji period, Kawaguchi anpan was a confectionery baked in an oven; it was made by employing the traditional baking technique because of the lack of information about anpan except for the name of anpan under the same situation as in making Tsukisamu anpan.

Originated during the early Meiji Period, Kawaguchi anpan was a confectionary baked in an oven; it was made employing traditional baking techniques due to the lack of information about the original anpan, similar to Tsukisamu anpan.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally and smoothly
sen.e: Originated during the early Meiji Period, Kawaguchi anpan was a confectionary baked in an oven; it was made employing traditional baking techniques due to the lack of information about the original anpan, similar to Tsukisamu anpan.

sen.j: 福島県須賀川市にはくまたぱんと呼ばれる駄菓子がある。
sen.e: There is also dagashi (cheap sweets) called kumatapan in Sukagawa City, Fukushima Prefecture.
There is also dagashi (cheap sweets) called kumatapan from Sukagawa City, Fukushima Prefecture.
There is also dagashi (cheap sweets) called kumatapan from Sukagawa City, Fukushima Prefecture.

sen.j: これは、小麦粉と黒糖で作った生地で餡を包んでオーブンで焼き上げた後、白砂糖をまぶした焼菓子である。
sen.e: This is a baked confectionary made by wrapping a core of bean paste in a skin of dough mixed with wheat flour and unrefined sugar, baking it in an oven, and dredging over it with white sugar.
Kumatapan is a baked confectionary made by wrapping a core of bean paste in a skin of dough mixed with wheat flour and unrefined sugar, baking it in an oven and sprinkling it with white sugar.
sen.cmt: changed "This" to "Kumatapan"; changed "dredging" to "sprinkling" for まぶした; fixed grammar
sen.e: Kumatapan is a baked confectionary made by wrapping a core of bean paste in a skin of dough mixed with wheat flour and unrefined sugar, baking it in an oven and sprinkling it with white sugar.

sen.j: 小豆系
sen.e: Paste made of red beans
Pastes made from red beans
Pastes made from red beans

sen.e: tsubuan
Tsubuan

Koshian

sen.e: shiroan
Shiroan
Shiroan

sen.e: Paste made by green beans
Pastes made from green beans
Pastes made from green beans

sen.j: 鶯餡
sen.e: uguisuan
Uguisuan
Uguisuan

sen.e: Pastes made of other ingredients
Pastes made from other ingredients
Pastes made from other ingredients

sen.j: イモあん
sen.e: imoan
Imoan
Imoan

sen.j: 栗あん
sen.e: kurian
Kurian

sen.j: 桜餡
sen.e: sakuraan
Sakuraan

tit.cmt: "Event" feels like a more natural word to use here than "Incident"

sen.j: - 明治天皇に木村屋のあんパンが献上された。
sen.e: The anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was presented to Meiji Emperor.
Anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was presented to the Meiji Emperor.
Anpan of the Kimuraya bakery was presented to the Meiji Emperor.
